review.title: Dynamic Knowledge Capitalization through Annotation among Economic Intelligence Actors in a Collaborative Environment
review.abstract: The shift from industrial economy to knowledge economy in today's world has revolutionalized strategic planning in organizations as well as their problem solving approaches. The point of focus today is knowledge and service production with more emphasis been laid on knowledge capital. Many organizations are investing on tools that facilitate knowledge sharing among their employees and they are as well promoting and encouraging collaboration among their staff in order to build the organization's knowledge capital with the ultimate goal of creating a lasting competitive advantage for their organizations. One of the current leading approaches used for solving organization's decision problem is the Economic Intelligence (EI) approach which involves interactions among various actors called EI actors. These actors collaborate to ensure the overall success of the decision problem solving process. In the course of the collaboration, the actors express knowledge which could be capitalized for future reuse. In this paper, we propose in the first place, an annotation model for knowledge elicitation among EI actors. Because of the need to build a knowledge capital, we also propose a dynamic knowledge capitalisation approach for managing knowledge produced by the actors. Finally, the need to manage the interactions and the interdependencies among collaborating EI actors, led to our third proposition which constitute an awareness mechanism for group work management.

metadata.title: Dynamic Knowledge Capitalization through Annotation among Economic Intelligence Actors in a Collaborative Environment

sections.text: The focus today is on knowledge and service production with a stronger focus on knowledge capital. Many organizations invest in tools that facilitate knowledge exchange between their employees, and they encourage and encourage collaboration between their employees to build the organization's knowledge capital, with the ultimate goal of creating a lasting competitive advantage for their organizations. One of the most common approaches to solving the organization's decision-making problem is the Economic Intelligence (EI) approach, which involves interactions between different actors, the so-called EI actors, who work together to ensure the overall success of the decision-making process. As part of the collaboration, the actors express knowledge that could be capitalized for future reuse. In this essay, we propose, first and foremost, an annotation model for knowledge generation among the EI actors. Due to the need to build a knowledge capital, we also propose a dynamic approach to knowledge capitalization that allows the labor group to manage the need for third parties to collaborate.
In this context, it should be noted that the solution to the problem is not only a problem, but also a problem that must be solved by the parties themselves.

Figure 1: The framework of the economic intelligence process [10] EI process begins with the decision maker expressing the decision problem as a form of document, referred to in [7] Initial Requirement. One such initial requirement is the materialized knowledge of the decision maker based on available information. Interactions between the actors on the initial request generate knowledge that could convey a mutual and clearer understanding of the objective of the decision problems. This could include the definition or explanation of some basic terms that could convey a clearer picture of the perception of the decision maker who may have formulated such a decision problem, as well as the identification and understanding of the goal to be achieved. Such knowledge could be captured through annotation. Shared perceptions provide more insight into possible solutions as the actors have a clearer understanding of each other's perception. Individuals can share their perceptions of the decision problem through comments in a collaborative environment.

AnchorfetchesstoreDocumentAnnotationDatabaseDocumentDatabasefetchesUser's profileUserDatabaseFigure 2: Logical view of annotation-as-process3 Dynamic Knowledge Capitalization Acquisition of the know-how and knowledge of actors acquired individually or in a collaborative environment in decision-making projects should be done in such a way that actors can utilize reliable and up-to-date knowledge. DC is an approach in which the acquisition of KR covers communication between actors in the course of solving a decision problem. The process of validating KR for achieving concessions between actors is also covered by annotation processes. DC is an approach in which the acquisition of KR covers communication between actors in the course of solving a decision problem.

Figure 3: DC Approach in the Context of EI3.1.1 Knowledge Elicitation, Acquisition and ValidationKR is elicited from stakeholders through the process of stakeholder-centric acquisition.Each task related to the EI process is handled by the respective stakeholders, so that their roles determine who should be elicited from KR. Interaction between stakeholders is continuously tracked and recorded.We proposed the process of declaration and commenting for this dynamic acquisition of KR. The declaration process allows stakeholders to declare KR in terms of their roles and context conditions. For example, a decision maker expresses a decision problem that can be externalized in the form of a document. The comment process is used to capture recurrent communication between stakeholders, which supports the need for proper understanding and validation of knowledge between them. Externalized knowledge is subjected to validation to ensure that a high degree of reliability is granted by stakeholders on the basis of the implementation of the RR.

Figure 4 illustrates this phase by showing the dynamic acquisition in a timestamp characterized by td for the declaration of the timestamp and ta for the timestamp of the annotation.Figure 4: Dynamic knowledge acquisition process 3.1.2 Knowledge representationWe represent knowledge resources using a conceptual knowledge model. This models the properties of KR and the relationship between them. The generic conceptual model shown in Figure 5 represents a general case applicable to problem solving processes in a domain.

Figure 5: Generic Conceptual Knowledge Model3.1.3 Storage with Temporary Attributes The acquired KR is stored with temporal attributes, i.e. with date / time stamp in a knowledge store. The temporal attributes of KR facilitate dynamics and non-volatile capitalization. Storing KR to instantiate the knowledge store facilitates the reuse of knowledge through exploitation processes. 3.1.4 Exploitation of acquired and stored KR can be used for reuse and dissemination. EQUA 2 (Explore, Query, Analyze and Annotate) [4] is used to exploit knowledge through query. The model initiates the query terms by proposing attributes of the content of Knowledge Repository to support the exploitation of relevant knowledge that meet meetactor's needs.

3.1.5 Feedback Exploitation StratyActors are guided to externalize the knowledge derived from the reuse of kr in the form of feedback. It encompasses the new problem and the assessment of the actor on the relevance of the kr being exploited. Thus, it is possible to evaluate such a KC system. Furthermore, the strategy leads to the knowledge repository developing while there is exploitation by actors. The method of realizing this approach is collaborative filtering. Thus, the DC approach facilitates actors to share knowledge gained during knowledge exploitation by capturing and storing generated feedback, as well as the generated kr. This is shown in Figure 6.Figure 6: Dynamic exploitation processThus, the system becomes dynamic as a result of a continuous update of knowledge reuse and capitalization of lessons by actors. 4. Managing interactions between collaborative actors When different actors work together in a collaborative environment, there is a need to coordinate their interactions.

Figure 8: Visualization of the knowledge expressed
Figure 9: DP definition in relation to use

Figure 10: Validation through annotation interface The implication of the proposed capitalization approach and the EICC system is that the creation and use of collaborative knowledge by stakeholders in the management of DP resolution produces validated or reliable knowledge available to them based on their needs. The second implemented system, called MECOCIR, handles the information process required to solve a decision-making problem, allowing stakeholders in the EI, especially information observers, to engage in synchronous and asynchronous collaboration during the problem-solving phase. Stakeholders can jointly propose relevant sources of information and jointly search for relevant information.

Figure 11 shows the main interface of MECOCIR. (1) Awareness Interface, (2) List of Cooperating Users, (3) Browser Interface for Online Search, (4) Cooperative Repository Interface, (5) Interface for Defining Information Problems, (6) Information Problems Comments Figure 11: MECOCIR Main Interface 12 3 56

The importance of knowledge capitalization in today's knowledge economy cannot be overstated. This paper discussed the knowledge capitalization approach in economic intelligence. We noted that EI actors collaborate in solving decision-making problems. During collaboration, there is a need for each actor to express their knowledge in a form that can be shared and understood by other actors. We proposed an annotation model that makes it possible to identify knowledge as an attribute-value pair in EI. Distinct knowledge is capitalized using our dynamic capitalization method. The need to manage interactions between collaborators led to the position of three levels of group consciousness. Our proposals were translated into EICC and MECOCIR. System.7. Reference [1]. referenceMentions.context: EI concerns the set of concepts, methods, and tools which unify all the coordinated actions of research, acquisition, treatment, storage and diffusion of information, relevant to individual or clustered enterprises and organizations in the framework of strategy [9].
It is a process that involves information collection, processing and distribution with the goal of reducing uncertainty in decision making [14].
All the EI phases involve actors who collaborate to produce actionable knowledge for decision making [10] [11].
All the EI phases involve actors who collaborate to produce actionable knowledge for decision making [10] [11].
Decision maker is the one capable of identifying and establishing the problem to be solved in terms of stake, of risk or threat on the enterprise [5].
In other words, he knows the needs of the organization, the stakes, the eventual risks and the threats the organization can be subjected to [1].
He is responsible for planning the work flow in EI process and coordinating the interactions among EI actors [10].

For explanation purpose, EI process could be translated into five phases [10]: - Translation phase: this phase concerns the identification of a decision problem and translating it to an information search problem.
If the decision problem is not properly identified and not properly translated then all the activities involved in the remaining four phases will be a waste [10].
Model for Decision Problem elicitation (MDP) [5] provides a way of representing stake.
This is what we refer to as protection of information patrimony [10].
Figure 1: Economic Intelligence process framework [10]
This is called initial demand in [7].
Annotation as object is defined as an intentional and topical value-adding note linked to an extant information object [2].
Annotation is also defined as “any object (annotation) that is associated with another object (document) by some relationship” [3].
The definition of annotation by [3] does not only consider annotation as object but also as an action involving anchoring the object with the concerned document.
Annotation as action is defined in [15] as an act of interpreting a document.
It is a method of eliciting knowledge from the annotator by capturing his interpretation on the document of interest [12].
1 Dynamic Capitalization of Knowledge Resources DC cycle [13] is depicted by figure 3.
EQUA 2 te (Explore, Query, Analyze and Annotate) model [4] is used for exploiting through query.
” [6] Group awareness is achieved by capturing each actor’s activities and the signals emanating from him/her in order to communicate them with his/her collaborators.
